title: How to help my child in school - Quora

response.answer_text: The best way to help your kids in school is to help them have a taste of success. And, well, they’ll want more. It’s a bit of a con job, but it works. Here’s how . . . Eventually, every kid will learn to multiply. It usually happens late in second grade. They will also learn about “opposites.” That’s basic kindergarten curriculum. In fourth grade, most school districts teach centrifugal force. In middle school, kids will learn how to bisect an angle with a compass and a straight edge. Your school district should be able to tell you exactly what they teach and when. So here’s what you do. Not the week before. Not the semester before. But YEARS before, go ahead and teach a few of these concepts to your kids. Make it a game! Do you know a three year old? Ask them “What’s the opposite of up?” They won’t know. Tell them with great sincerity, “The opposite of up is down!” Then ask them, “What is the opposite of cold?” They won’t know. Tell them the “The opposite of cold is hot!” Do the same with big/little, loud/quiet, slow/fast, closed/open, nice/mean, clean/dirty, yes/no, off/on, etc. Use your best vocal expressiveness, use your hands, look in their face, mime the answer as you say it. After four or five examples, suddenly their little face lights up and they understand! It’s amazing. It’s a rush for them and for you. In a couple years, when the kindergarten teacher starts teaching “opposites,” your kid is going to be top of the class. Suddenly, they will be earmarked as a bright student worthy of special attention the rest of their school career. This is strategic parenting. Going into kindergarten all the moms have already made sure their kids know colors, ABCs, and two plus two. But only your kid will know “opposites.” The best part is that you taught them! Do the same with multiplication when your kid is in first grade. But don’t ask, “What is five times two?” That sounds confusing. That’s work. Instead, ask “What is five, two times?” Use your hands as demonstration. Then ask, “What is four, two times?” Then ask, “What is four, three times!” A sharp first grader (your kid) will get it. Be warned, you’ve turned learning into a game and they may never want to stop. That’s when you know you have put them way ahead of the curve. One more example. On the next nice day, invite your second grader out to your driveway to wash your car. Ask them if they think you can hold the bucket of water upside down over your head without spilling it. They will laugh and say “No way, daddy!” Then spin that bucket over your head without losing a drop. They’ll be amazed, and you will have demonstrated centrifugal and centripetal force. (Look it up, if you don’t remember.) You can see how this concept is a bit sneaky. Your kid may or may not actually be any smarter than the other kids. Still, everyone in that classroom — including the teachers — has new heightened expectations for your child’s performance. Funny thing about expectations. They tend to come true. (Excerpted from the best-seller, 52 Things Kids Need from a Dad.)

Depending on their age, read to them. My father used to read parts of “The Atlantic” to me even when I was a young teen. He used to read a bedtime story that HE enjoyed, usually classics. Let your children see you reading all sorts of things from the newspaper to non-fiction magazines such as Time of Scientific American. If your family sees or does something interesting, help them look it up and learn more about it, BUT don’t make it a forced march. I used to have friends whose parents just about killed learning joy by forcing it too much. Go to the library and borrow a book or two that is just resting in the family room for all to see/read bit of. Do this before/and after a trip to the beach. Get a do-it-yourself book and follow it through a task. Always have a book on the go and read it when waiting for an appointment. Depending on the age, ask for help when balancing a check book or checking a credit card. Get them to help you with the math. Watch Animal Planet type shows and talk about it. Discuss what was your most or least favorite and why. The main idea is to make sure your children have a good model in you. Talk to them about feelings and emotions. Try to not be judgmental.

Be an example of a studious person. Show them you are a reader, let them pay the cashier, and show them you are interested in education venues. I don't have to help my kids in school, and maybe it's because I read books with them and fight over who gets to first read the newest books we get from Amazon. My husband shows them the stars and they watch ant documentaries together. They all get good grades and if they need help, they know we are here.

Be cheerful about it. Ask them about their day. Develop a consistent pattern. My kids came home, walked up our very long driveway. Ate a snack, played outside to burn up some energy. They sat at our big Breakfast Bar doing homework while I fixed dinner. Or helped cooking. I was right there to help. They helped clean up dinner.
